intro: Thesium cytisoides, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to parts of Africa and Asia. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and typically grows on the branches of trees and shrubs. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered leaves and yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in spring. Its berries are red and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. Thesium cytisoides has a symbiotic relationship with its host, drawing water and nutrients while providing no direct benefit to the host plant.
